text:
Is there a way to implicitly convert two variables with the same *intrinsic type* but coming from different modules? see below for example
```LoadError: MethodError: no method matching synthetise_schedule(::Array{Main.Scheduler.Loader.Entities.Agent,1}, ::Array{<http://Main.Scheduler.Loader.Entities.Space|Main.Scheduler.Loader.Entities.Space>,1}, ::Dict{String,Array{String,1}})
Closest candidates are:
synthetise_schedule(::Array{Main.Scheduler.Entities.Agent,1}, ::Array{<http://Main.Scheduler.Entities.Space|Main.Scheduler.Entities.Space>,1}, ::Dict{String,Array{String,1}}) ```
For instance,
`<http://Main.Scheduler.Loader.Entities.Space|Main.Scheduler.Loader.Entities.Space>` and `<http://Main.Scheduler.Entities.Space|Main.Scheduler.Entities.Space>` refer to the same element but for some reason they are not considered the same type.
I don’t export types in any of my modules and sub-modules, but I have the following `using` statements at the top of my `Scheduler`  module
```using .Loader: load_data, read_config
using .Entities: Agent, Space, Event```

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

Success, it has been cross posted <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/55006| to Discourse>. Keep and eye out on Discourse for responses and please add an answer there once you are satisfied with the solution so others can benefit as well. Happy debugging!

```module A
  export MyType

  struct MyType
    x::Int
  end
end

module B
  export MyType

  struct MyType
    x::Int
  end
end

using .A: MyType # works
using .B: MyType # warns 
WARNING: ignoring conflicting import of B.MyType into Main```
You should be importing the shared type from one place
```module A
  export MyType
  
  struct MyType
    x::Int
  end
end

module B
   using ..A:MyType
   # ...
end

module C
  using ..A:MyType
  # ...
end

using .B: MyType # ok
using .C: MyType # ok```

WARNING: ignoring conflicting import of B.MyType into Main
You should be importing the shared type from one place

module A
  export MyType
  
  struct MyType
    x::Int
  end
end

module B
   using ..A:MyType
   # ...
end

module C
  using ..A:MyType
  # ...
end

using .B: MyType # ok
using .C: MyType # ok

Thanks, but still super confused and I think your example is not really replicable in my case.
In the diagram below, I don’t export anything neither in the `Loader` or `Entities` module. How come the REPL not understand that `Main.Scheduler.Loader.Entities.Agent`  and `Main.Scheduler.Entities.Agent` are the same elements?

text: Nope, only in Entities
is it exported from Entities?
Nope
Why not?
I guess I wanted to avoid potential future conflicts.

elements.text: I guess I wanted to avoid potential future conflicts.

text: So anytime I need it in another module I do `Entities.Agent`

elements.text: So anytime I need it in another module I do

text: That is not the most appropriate way.  The purpose of `export` is to allow other modules to get use of the (here) type in a way that does not allow conflicts.

elements.text: That is not the most appropriate way.  The purpose of
is to allow other modules to get use of the (here) type in a way that does not allow conflicts.

text: OK, so I if `export Agent` in the `Entities` module, do I need to `using Entities: Agent` as well?

You should write `export Agent` near the top of you `Entities` module...
Any module other than `Entities` in which you want to utilize `Agent`
should have `using Entities` or `using Entities: Agent`  near the top of the file

elements.text: in which you want to utilize
near the top of the file

text: `using Entities` is the same as `using Entities: Agent, <other exports from Entities>`

elements.text: using Entities: Agent, <other exports from Entities>

text: Gotcha — i’ll try
:ok_hand::skin-tone-3:
Still doesn’t work — it seems like even if I use `using` and `export`, Julia REPL makes a new copy of the type every time it’s used in a new module.
